docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THE DUKES OF HAZZARD: THE BEGINNING (2007). April Scott, who hails from Poplar Bluff, Mo., the so-called gateway to the Ozarks, plays Daisy Duke in this made-for-television prequel based on the series about a couple of rabble-rousing Southern cousins. Jonathan Bennett plays Bo Hazzard, Randy Wayne (above right, with Mr. Bennett and Ms. Scott) is his cousin Luke, and Christopher McDonald gets gussied up in white as Boss Hogg. Willie Nelson, who played Uncle Jesse in the 2005 Jessica Simpson-Johnny Knoxville big-screen version, reprises the role here. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS -- Principal Skinner offers Lisa a chance to tutor Cletus Spuckler's hillbilly children. Meanwhile, Bart has to see a psychiatrist (voiced by Meg Ryan) after he claims the school cafeteria is haunted. Stephen Sondheim and Andy Dick have cameos as themselves. 8 P.M. (Travel) SAND BLASTERS 2007: THE EXTREME SAND SCULPTING CHAMPIONSHIPS -- These are not your little brother's sand castles. In this two-part special, 16 sand sculptors try out their wizardry on Pacific Beach in San Diego for a $15,000 prize. 8:30 P.M. (Fox) THE WINNER -- You have to grow up sometime. In this new sitcom, set in 1994, Glen Abbott (Rob Corddry, left) -- a 32-year-old late bloomer still living with his parents -- comes of age when Allison (Erinn Hayes), the only girl he has ever kissed, returns to town a divorcee with a teenage son and inspires him to become a man. The twist: it's present-day Glen who's narrating this story, and he is now the richest man in Buffalo. 9 P.M. (ABC) DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES -- Rex Van De Kamp is roused from the dead just long enough to narrate the happenings on Wisteria Lane from a male perspective. Tonight, Edie gets an unexpected visitor from her past and an unplanned pregnancy throws a wrench into someone's plans. 9 P.M. (Discovery) THE LOST TOMB OF JESUS -- The filmmaker James Cameron is executive producer of this documentary, which is already stirring up controversy. The premise: There is credible evidence that a 2,000-year-old tomb in the Talpiot neighborhood of Jerusalem once held the remains of Jesus of Nazareth and his family -- including his wife, Mary Magdalene, and son, Judah. 9 P.M. (CNBC) THE BUSINESS OF INNOVATION -- Maria Bartiromo, the CNBC ''Money Honey'' who was recently in the news when her flight on a corporate jet was cited as one of the reasons for a Citigroup executive's downfall, is the host of this five-part series. 10 P.M. (ABC) BROTHERS & SISTERS -- It's a shocker. Turns out William Walker and Holly Harper (Patricia Wettig) have an illegitimate daughter, Rebecca (Emily VanCamp). KATHRYN SHATTUCK

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Daughter's Death, and a Quest for Answers,'' by George A. Goens (Generations, Feb. 18):
docs.abstract: Sree Mukherjee Vaid, Dr Debra Gussman, Barbara Fischer and Arnold Goodman letters on George Goens's February 18 Generations essay on death of his daughter during childbirth
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''A Daughter's Death, and a Quest for Answers,'' by George A. Goens (Generations, Feb. 18):

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''They Think They've Been Cursed by God,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, Feb. 25), highlights the terrible suffering millions of women endure from crippling childbirth injuries. Having visited camps for internally displaced persons in northern Uganda last week, I can personally attest to the dire need for family planning in this war-torn region. Our team met with about 140 women, many of whom were desperate for contraception. Spacing pregnancies can save children's lives.
docs.abstract: Four letters comment on Nicholas D Kristof Feb 25 Op-Ed column on global maternal health; Sandra Krause, reproductive health project director for Women's Commission for Refugee Women and Children, says women need safe and effective contraception; Rep Carolyn B Maloney says she plans to introduce legislation to combat obstetric fistula; Laura Katzive, deputy director of International Legal Program of Center for Reproductive Rights, says governments are failing on issue of maternal health; Elizabeth Mach says global maternal health programs must be made priority; drawing
